conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light. The size and position of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows directly below them.
It increases the angle between the light rays and the surface on which the shadows are cast.
The shadows will shift forward, moving closer to the objects.
The size of the shadows will decrease because the angle of the light rays becomes more perpendicular to the surface, reducing the elongation of the shadows.

Shadow B (Rectangular Object) moves closer to the object.
Shadow C (Cylindrical Object) moves closer to the object.
